item.title: Here's How People Are Actually Using Bitcoin | VICE | Canada
item.description:
Here's How People Are Actually Using Bitcoin | VICE | Canada

Thumbnail image via Wikicommons Bitcoin is a cipher-literally and figuratively. The crypto-currency conjures a William Gibson-esque panorama of dark web Tor servers, masked figures cavorting in Eastern European shipping containers, multibillion dollar South American cartel-laundering operations, gaunt college sophomores picking up Silk Road designer drugs at liberal arts-school mailboxes, and so forth.

item.title: Mass Network to Offer Bitcoin-Based Solution to Online Ads
item.description:
Mass Network to Offer Bitcoin-Based Solution to Online Ads

A recent Also read: 'Bitcoin Browser' Brave Raises $4.5M, Readies for 1.0 Launch press release reveals that a group of cryptography experts, advertisers and industry executives have formed what they call " The Mass Network ." This project aims to provide a blockchain-based solution to the problems of online advertising, such as pop-ups and exploitative practices.

item.title: Building a new Tor that can resist next-generation state surveillance
item.description:
Building a new Tor that can resist next-generation state surveillance

Since Edward Snowden stepped into the limelight from a hotel room in Hong Kong three years ago, the use of Tor, the anonymous Internet browser, has grown massively.

item.title: Can you run a city with blockchain?
item.description:
Can you run a city with blockchain?

Answer: "Just because you CAN doesn't mean you SHOULD" That said the short answer is YES. A distributed ledger in fact would provide much needed transaprency in terms of civil service operations. They literally have no idea what it costs to the city.

item.title: In a Corda blockchain (R3 CEV), will the block be replicated on every member node of the private blockchain?
item.description:
In a Corda blockchain (R3 CEV), will the block be replicated on every member node of the private blockchain?

Wait, what? You won't "allow" it? Is this person your husband or your child? If you treat your husband like a child and believe you have the right to allow or not allow him to do what he wants, you are laying the groundwork for your future divorce.

item.title: Besides having your medical records on the blockchain what are the other uses cases of blockchain in healthcare?
item.description:
Besides having your medical records on the blockchain what are the other uses cases of blockchain in healthcare?

This question needs editing to be improved. It may need to be reworded as a fully formed question, need spelling, grammar, or formatting improved (learn more about formatting on Quora), be ambiguous or difficult to understand, be too reliant on question details, be directed at a specific person, or overly verbose.

item.title: The FBI Speaks Out Again About Encryption
item.description:
The FBI Speaks Out Again About Encryption

James Comey, Director of the FBI, is speaking out again. Issuing another warning on Tuesday about the bureau still not being able to get into encrypted devices. He says that widespread encryption that is being built into smartphones, is making the area they are in charge of investigating "dark".

Ethereum Price Technical Analysis - ETH Poised For Gains? - NEWSBTC

Ethereum price managed to pop higher against the US dollar, and currently looks positive for more gains in the near term. Ethereum price managed to pop higher against the US dollar, and currently looks positive for more gains in the near term.

item.title: How can superconnectors make use of blockchain/be rewarded by it?
item.description:
How can superconnectors make use of blockchain/be rewarded by it?

Answer: First thought: as a distributed and inherently public network of trust blockchain might be useful for memorializing social transactions, i.e. X did a favor for Y. Second thought: this could be monetized via the 21 (software platform) for microcommerce. More if I think of it.

item.title: German savers lose faith in banks
item.description:
German savers lose faith in banks

HAMBURG--German savers are leaving the security of savings banks for what many now consider an even safer place to park their cash: home safes. For years, Germans kept socking money away in savings accounts despite plunging interest rates. Savers deemed the accounts secure, and they still offered easy cash access.
